p: In the past, antibacterial properties were mainly reported by minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) which is described as the lowest concentration of an agent to prevent bacterial visible growth ( 12). For instance, the MIC of Artemisia dracunculus EO on S. aureus was 62.4 mg.mL –1 ( 13). Besides, Anethum graveolens EO showed a good antibacterial effect on E. coli with MIC of 2.5 mg.mL –1 ( 14). However, by developing optical density (OD) dependent technics, the growth of microorganisms was observed as turbidity, determined by analytical instruments ( 15). By investigating the antibacterial activity of active agents at various concentrations and using software such as CalcuSyn, half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50) is measurable. This value is defined as observing a 50% decrease in bacterial growth in the treated sample compared to the control group. It is a reliable and quantitative unit with upper and lower confidence limits ( 16).
